item.title: The Hundred
item.description: The Hundred is Joseph Pilates’ signature exercise and the traditional opening of every classical Pilates mat routine. It’s designed to warm up your body, engage your powerhouse (core), and coordinate your breath with movement. Why It’s Called “The Hundred” You pump your arms 100 times total while holding your core engaged. This creates internal heat and prepares your body for the exercises that follow. Benefits Core Endurance: Holding the position builds stamina in your deep abdominal muscles Breath Coordination: The rhythmic breathing pattern oxygenates your blood Full Body Warm-Up: Engages arms, core, and legs simultaneously Mind-Body Connection: Requires focus and concentration Common Mistakes to Avoid Tensing the neck - Keep your gaze at your belly button, not the ceiling Holding your breath - Maintain the 5-count inhale, 5-count exhale pattern Arching the lower back - Press your lower back gently into the mat Pumping from shoulders - Initiate the arm movement from your lats Tips for Success Start with the beginner modification and progress over time Quality over quantity - better to do 50 pumps with proper form than 100 with poor form Focus on the exhale to deepen your core engagement

item.title: The Roll Up
item.description: The Roll Up is one of the most challenging mat exercises and a true test of core strength. It requires controlled articulation of the spine - moving one vertebra at a time - which builds both strength and flexibility. Benefits Core Strength: Targets deep abdominal muscles Spinal Mobility: Improves vertebrae-by-vertebrae movement Flexibility: Stretches the entire back body Control: Develops mind-muscle connection Tips for Success Imagine peeling your spine off the mat like a wheel Keep your feet grounded throughout the movement Move slowly - momentum is cheating!
